header.title: The Lesser Key of Solomon
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Tradition, Goetia, Demonology, Angel Magic

central_thesis: The Lesser Key of Solomon presents a comprehensive system for the evocation, command, and communication with various classes of spiritual entities (including infernal spirits, aerial spirits, planetary angels, and zodiacal angels) to acquire knowledge, power, assistance, and magical effects, purportedly based on the practices of King Solomon. It meticulously details the necessary rituals, tools, seals, and prayers for operative magic within the Solomonic tradition.

structure_content.summary: Briefly thanks the British Museum for providing access to manuscripts used in the compilation.
Lists the abbreviations for various manuscript sources and references cited throughout the text.

Provides an historical overview of the Lemegeton, its origins, various manuscripts, and its five constituent parts. It contextualizes the work by referencing earlier magical texts and authors like Agrippa and Weyer, and discusses the editorial methodology, primarily relying on Sloane MS 3825.

Defines magic as the 'highest absolute and divinest knowledge of Natural Philosophy,' distinguishing Natural from Diabolical Magic. It introduces the purpose and content of the 'Booke of Spirits' as containing names, orders, offices, seals, and methods for evoking spirits encountered by Solomon.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Of the Arte Goetia
structure_content.summary: Details the seventy-two infernal spirits, their hierarchical order, appearance, offices (powers), and unique seals or characters. It includes the specific conjurations and constraints required to compel these spirits to visible appearance and obedience.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part II: The Art Theurgia Goetia
structure_content.summary: Describes thirty-one chief aerial spirits and their numerous ministering spirits. It outlines their nature (partly good, partly evil), seals, and conjurations, emphasizing the importance of directing invocations towards the spirits' abode points on the compass.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part III: The Art Pauline of King Salomon
structure_content.summary: Divided into two parts, this section focuses on angels associated with the hours of the day and night, and angels linked to the signs of the Zodiac. It provides seals and invocations, stressing astrological timing for effective operation.

Explains the construction of the Almadel (a wax tablet) and its use for invoking angels of the four altitudes of the world. It specifies the colors for the Almadel and candles, and describes the appearance and nature of these angels.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part V: Ars Notoria: The Notary Art of Salomon
structure_content.summary: Presents a collection of orations and prayers aimed at acquiring knowledge, memory, and eloquence directly through divine revelation and angelic assistance. It discusses the proper timing for these orations and their efficacy in various sciences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix 1: Addenda found in Sloane 2731 and 3648
structure_content.summary: Includes supplementary material such as lists of names, experiments for recovering stolen goods, and explanations of the Circle and Triangle of Solomon, along with alternate spirit versions.
Presents an excerpt from Johann Weyer's influential work, which lists demons and their attributes, serving as a significant comparative text and source for portions of the Goetia.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix 3: Comparison of Goetia with Weyer
structure_content.summary: A table comparing the names and hierarchical order of spirits found in the Goetia with those in Weyer's Pseudomonarchia Daemonum, highlighting similarities and differences.

structure_content.chapter_title: Appendix 4: Other examples of some of the drawings
structure_content.summary: Provides additional illustrations of sigils, magical figures, and planetary characters from various manuscripts, offering visual context to the magical implements and entities described.

key_concepts.definition: The overarching title for the collection of five books, meaning 'Little Key of Solomon,' a handbook of sorcery from the 17th century, though material dates earlier. (p. 9)
The first book, dealing with 72 infernal spirits, their seals, and methods of evocation and constraint. Associated with 'unclean spirits.' (p. 10, 21)
The second book, concerning 31 chief aerial spirits and their subordinates, described as 'partly good and partly evill.' (p. 12, 21)
The third book, involving spirits governing planetary hours and zodiacal signs, categorized as 'good' spirits. (p. 12, 21)
The fourth book, detailing 20 chief spirits governing the four Altitudes (corners of the world) and their seals, used with a wax Almadel. Categorized as 'good' spirits. (p. 13, 21)
The fifth book, a Medieval grimoire focused on orations and prayers to acquire knowledge, memory, and eloquence through divine revelation and angelic agency. (p. 14, 22)
Various entities categorized by the Lemegeton into infernal, aerial (partly good/evil), and good (planetary, zodiacal, Almadel). Each has specific forms, offices, legions, and seals/characters.
Unique sigils for each spirit, required to be worn by the magician during invocation to ensure obedience and homage. (e.g., Bael, p. 23)
A nine-foot circle with divine names written around its perimeter, used for the magician's protection and as a space for spirit manifestation. (p. 57-58)
A two-foot wide, three-foot long triangle placed two feet from the circle, where the evoked spirit is commanded to appear. (p. 58)
A silver ring worn on the middle finger of the left hand, held to the face, for protection against offensive spirit fumes (e.g., Astaroth) and for commanding spirits. (p. 29, 60)
A brass container into which King Solomon purportedly bound 72 kings and princes of spirits; seals and offerings are placed into it during rituals. (p. 55, 61-62)
A talismanic plate, often worn on the breast, bearing the spirit's seal, essential for commanding the spirit. (e.g., Bael, p. 23)
The ritualized spoken commands and invocations using divine names to compel spirits to appear and obey. (p. 64, 65, 68)

practical_system.description: The system described in 'The Lesser Key of Solomon' is a comprehensive Solomonic grimoire tradition focused on the evocation and command of various spiritual entities, categorized as infernal spirits, aerial spirits (good and evil), planetary angels, zodiacal angels, and angels of the four altitudes. The magic operates on the principle of compelling spirits through divine names, specific seals, and precise ritual timing, often involving astrological correspondences. The goal is to gain knowledge, power, assistance in various matters (e.g., finding treasures, causing love/hatred, healing, arts, wisdom), and protection.
tools: Lamen/Seals/Characters: Talismanic plates bearing the unique sigils of spirits, made of specific metals or parchment, worn by the magician for authority and compulsion. (e.g., Bael's Character, p. 23; Pentagonal Figure, p. 60)
Magic Circle: A nine-foot circle inscribed with divine names, serving as a protective barrier and sacred space for the operator. (p. 57-58)
Triangle: A two-foot wide, three-foot long triangle placed outside the circle, where spirits are commanded to appear. (p. 58)
Magical Ring (of Solomon): A silver ring worn on the left middle finger, held to the face for protection against harmful spirit effluvia and for command. (p. 29, 60)
Brazen Vessel: A brass pot into which Solomon reputedly bound spirits, used for compelling recalcitrant spirits. (p. 61-62)
Hazel Stick: Used to 'allay courage' of furious spirits (e.g., Beleth). (p. 29)
Vestments: White linen robe, miter or cap, girdle of Lyons skin, shoes. (p. 47)
Perfumes/Incense: Used to 'smoke or perfume' the ritual space and for offerings. (p. 47, 149)
Almadel: A square wax tablet, often colored according to altitude, used for invoking angels of the four altitudes. (p. 161)
Candles: Four candles of the same color as the Almadel, placed on waxen feet to support the Almadel. (p. 162)
Black Box with Brimstone/Asafetida: Used to punish and compel disobedient spirits by burning their name and seal. (p. 68)
Parchment/Clean Paper: For writing seals and names. (p. 112)
rituals: Preparation: Involves ritual purification (inward and outward cleanness, fasting, prayers for pardon), constructing specific magical tools, and wearing special vestments.
Timing: Operations are strictly tied to lunar phases, planetary hours, specific days of the week, and zodiacal signs, as these influence the nature and obedience of the spirits. (p. 56, 79, 94, 125)

Evocation/Conjuration: Involves standing within a consecrated Magic Circle, commanding spirits to appear in a designated Triangle, and using specific divine names and lengthy orations ('First Conjuration', 'Second Conjuration', 'Constraint', 'Conjuration of the Fire'). (p. 64-68)
Communication & Command: Once appeared, spirits are questioned and commanded to fulfill the magician's desires.
Licensing to Depart: After successful operation, spirits are formally released and licensed to depart 'peacebly and quietly.' (p. 71)
Specific rituals for Ars Notoria: Involve reading specific orations multiple times daily or or during certain lunar phases to acquire knowledge, memory, and eloquence. (p. 178-198)

relevant_quotes.text: Magick is the highest most absolute and divinest knowledge of Natural Philosophy advanced in its works and wonderfull operations by a right understanding of the inward and occult vertue of things, so that true agents being applyed to proper patients, strange and admirable effects will thereby be produced; whence magicians are profound & diligent searchers into Nature; they because of their skill know how to anticipate an effect which to the vulgar shall seeme a miracle.

The Lemegeton is a popular handbook of sorcery known from the 17th century in more or less the same form as I will present it. Most of the material, however, is found in varying forms in earlier manuscripts, and some of the material dates back as early as the 14th century or earlier.
The lesser key of Solomon lemegeton clavicula Salomonis / Joseph H. Peterson, editor

This Booke contains all the names, Orders, and Offices of all the spirits Salomon ever conversed with. The seales and characters belonging to each spirit, and the manner of calling them forth to visible appearance. Some of these spirits are in Enock's Tables which I have explained, but omitted their seales and characters, how they may be knowne; but in this booke they are at large set forth.
The first part, is a Book of evill spirits, called Goetia, shewing how he bound up those spirits and used them in severall things, wherby he obtained great fame.

Goetia is a Greek term more or less synonymous with magic, but with negative connotations, as distinguished from the more elevated Theurgia ("working of a god"). The compiler of the Lemegeton certainly recognized this distinction.

This secreet seal is to be made by one that is cleane both Inward and outward, and hath not defiled himself by any woman in the space of a Month; but hath with fasting and prayers to God desired pardon of all his sins, &c: Itt is to be made on a Tuesday or Saturday night at 12 of the Clock, written with the Blood of a Black Cock which never trode hen, on virgins parchment, Note, on those nights the Â» must be encreasing in 11R, when it [is] so made, fume it with Allum, Raisins of the Sun, dates, Cedar & lignum Aloes, by this seal Salomon compelled the aforesaide spirits into a Brass vessel, and sealed it up with the same, he by it gained the love of all Manner of persons, and overcame in Battle, for neither weapon fire nor water could hurt him.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Lesser Key of Solomon is highly relevant in Western Esotericism as one of the most influential and widely studied grimoires. It forms a foundational text for many modern ceremonial magic traditions, particularly those involving demonology (Goetia). Its detailed instructions for spirit evocation, sigil creation, and ritual preparation have shaped subsequent magical systems and remain a practical guide for practitioners seeking direct experience with various spiritual entities. It offers insight into the historical development of Solomonic magic and the syncretic nature of occult traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The text is primarily aimed at advanced students and practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in Solomonic grimoire traditions, demonology, and angel magic. Its complex rituals, extensive lists of spirits, and specific astrological timing requirements necessitate a dedicated and knowledgeable individual with a strong foundation in occult philosophy and practice. It is not suitable for beginners due to the inherent dangers and complexities described, and the need for significant preparation and understanding to avoid 'temptations of Sathan' or 'unclean spirits.'
